contentrichtext.text: {{distinguish2|[[Newton (unit)]], the SI unit of force}} {{temperature}} The '''Newton scale''' is a [[temperature]] scale devised by [[Isaac Newton]] around 1700. Applying his mind to the problem of [[heat]], he elaborated a first qualitative temperature scale, comprising about twenty reference points ranging from "cold air in winter" to "glowing coals in the kitchen fire". This approach was rather crude and problematic, so Newton quickly became dissatisfied with it. He knew that most substances expand when heated, so he took a container of [[linseed oil]] and measured its change of [[volume]] against his reference points. He found that the volume of linseed oil grew by 7.25% when heated from the temperature of melting [[snow]] to that of boiling water. After a while, he defined the "zeroth degree of heat" as melting snow and "33 degrees of heat" as boiling water. His scale is thus a precursor of the [[Celsius scale]], being defined by the same temperature references. Indeed it is likely that Celsius knew about the Newton scale when he invented his. Newton called his instrument a "[[thermometer]]". Thus the [[units of measurement|unit]] of this scale, the Newton degree, equals {{sfrac|100|33}} (approximately 3.03) [[kelvin]] or degrees [[Celsius]] and has the same zero as the [[Celsius]] scale. ==Conversion table between the different temperature units== {{Timeline Temperature Conversion}} ==See also== * [[Comparison of temperature scales]] ==References== *{{Citation |first=U. |last=Grigull |title=Newton's temperature scale and the law of cooling |journal=Heat and Mass Transfer |volume=18 |issue=4 |year=1984 |doi=10.1007/BF01007129 |pages=195â€“199 |bibcode = 1984W&S....18..195G }}. ==External links== *[http://www.scienceandsociety.co.uk/results.asp?image=10413117&wwwflag=&imagepos=43 Photo of an antique thermometer backing board c. 1758]—marked in four scales; the first is Newton's. {{TemperatureScales}} [[Category:Obsolete units of measurement]] [[Category:Units of temperature]]
